def: A poisonous amido acid, C6H13NO2, separated by Brieger fromdecaying horseflesh. In physiological action, it is similar tocurare.
With a harsh, grating sound or voice.
Old; as, Auld Reekie (old smoky), i. e., Edinburgh. [Scot. &Prov. Eng.]
That which stands in the way, or opposes; anything that hindersprogress; a hindrance; an obstruction, physical or moral.If all obstacles were cut away. And that my path were even to thecrown. Shak.
Not stable; not standing fast or firm; unstable; prone tochange or recede from a purpose; mutable; inconstant.
Of, pertaining to, or resembling, the family of plants of whichthe bindweed and the morning-glory are common examples.

Of the nature of an outrage; exceeding the limits of right,reason, or decency; involving or doing an outrage; furious; violent;atrocious. "Outrageous weeping." Chaucer. "The most outrageousvillainies." Sir P. Sidney. "The vile, outrageous crimes." Shak."Outrageous panegyric." Dryden.
The condition or quality of being convertible; capability ofbeing exchanged; convertibleness.The mutual convertibility of land into money, and of money into land.Burke.
Of or pertaining to obsequies; funereal. [R.] "To do obsequioussorrow." Shak.
